channel.title: WSJ.com: World News

item.title: BOE Set For Modest Rate Cuts As Inflation Stays High, NIESR Says
item.description: Inflation is likely to remain stubbornly high this year, the National Institute of Economic and Social Research said as it cut is 2025 growth forecast for the U.K.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon

item.title: The ‘Narco-Subs’ Helping to Flood Europe With Cocaine
item.description: The Wall Street Journal went out on patrol with customs agents in northern Spain who scour the coast for drug traffickers.
item.dc:creator: Eve Hartley

item.title: Trump’s Threats Push Greenlanders Closer to Denmark
item.description: The prospect of American annexation has reinvigorated ties between the island and Copenhagen, though aspirations for independence persist.
item.dc:creator: Yaroslav Trofimov

item.title: Shippers Are Skeptical of Trump’s Truce With the Houthis
item.description: With an unclear deal and the Gaza war continuing, top carriers have no plans to return to the Red Sea soon.
item.dc:creator: Benoit Faucon

item.title: Fentanyl Crisis Provided Opening for U.S.-China Trade Talks
item.description: A planned meeting in Switzerland will be the first direct talks over trade during Trump’s second term.
item.dc:creator: Alex Leary

item.title: Libya’s Leaders Say They Haven’t Agreed to Accept Deported Migrants From the U.S.
item.description: A court says the Trump administration can’t deport people to Libya without giving them proper notice, presenting yet another hurdle for the plans.
item.dc:creator: Alexander Ward

item.title: India and Pakistan Face Off but Seek to Contain Fallout
item.description: Despite the increased violence, including cross-border shelling, both sides appeared to be calibrating their moves to avoid a descent into full-blown conflict.
item.dc:creator: Tripti Lahiri

item.title: Syria Dangles Oil, Peace for U.S. Help on Sanctions
item.description: The former Islamist rebels who run the new government are looking to convince a skeptical Trump administration
item.dc:creator: Jared Malsin

item.title: Are India and Pakistan at Risk of War? Here’s What We Know
item.description: The latest on the confrontation between the nuclear-armed neighbors over the disputed Muslim-majority region of Kashmir.
item.dc:creator: Shan Li

item.title: China Lowers Rates and Makes Bank Lending Easier in Response to Tariffs
item.description: In its first concrete steps since Trump ratcheted up tariffs, Beijing stuck to its incremental approach to addressing economic pain.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Feng

item.title: Who Will Be the Next Pope? A Visual Guide to the Conclave
item.description: Some 133 cardinals of the Catholic Church are casting their votes for a successor to Pope Francis. Get to know the key players and factions.
item.dc:creator: Victoria Rosselli

item.title: U.S. and Chinese Officials to Meet for Trade Talks
item.description: Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent and Trade Representative Jamieson Greer are traveling to Switzerland to meet Beijing’s lead economic representative, potentially paving the way for broader trade talks.
item.dc:creator: Lingling Wei

item.title: India Launches Military Strikes Against Pakistan
item.description: Pakistan said 26 people were killed in the strikes that India said were in retaliation for a militant attack on tourists in Kashmir.
item.dc:creator: Shan Li

item.title: Venezuelan Opposition Activists Freed After Hiding From Maduro Regime
item.description: Secretary of State Marco Rubio says the five activists are now on U.S. soil following “a precise operation” in the Venezuelan capital.
item.dc:creator: Juan Forero

item.title: Corpses for Cash: How Corruption Stalks Ukraine’s War Dead
item.description: The funeral trade can be a lucrative source of income. In Pokrovsk, the last remaining grave digger’s only focus is burying the dead.
item.dc:creator: Alistair MacDonald

item.title: The Vatican Financial Mess Pope Francis Couldn’t Fix
item.description: The next pope will inherit a soaring deficit and culture of financial malpractice that Francis tried and failed to solve even through his final weeks.
item.dc:creator: Stacy Meichtry

item.title: Carney, Meeting Trump, Says Canada Isn’t for Sale
item.description: President Trump repeated his suggestion that Canada become the 51st state in an otherwise collegial White House meeting with Prime Minister Mark Carney.
item.dc:creator: Alex Leary

item.title: Trump Says Truce Reached With Houthis After They Promise to Stop Targeting Ships
item.description: The announcement came after a weekslong U.S. campaign of airstrikes targeting the group.
item.dc:creator: Michael R. Gordon

item.title: Germany’s Merz Becomes Chancellor on Second Try but Emerges Weakened
item.description: The conservative politician had unexpectedly failed to secure enough support in the initial round of parliamentary voting.
item.dc:creator: Bertrand Benoit

item.title: Israel Strikes Houthi Airport in Second Day of Retaliatory Attacks
item.description: The military’s strikes in Yemen followed a Houthi attack on Tel Aviv’s Ben Gurion Airport on Sunday.

item.title: EU Lays Out Plan to Cut Russian Energy Imports by 2027
item.description: As part of its plan, the EU executive arm in June will propose a ban on all imports of Russian gas—both pipeline and LNG—under new and existing spot contracts. The measure would take effect by year-end.
item.dc:creator: Giulia Petroni

item.title: Israel Is Heading for a Full Occupation of Gaza—and All the Risks It Entails
item.description: The plan could expose Israel to additional legal requirements toward the civilian population and risk ensnaring the military in a long-term quagmire.
item.dc:creator: Feliz Solomon

item.title: How Images of the Dalai Lama’s Hands, Feet Landed a Tibetan Woman in China’s Dragnet
item.description: The rare account of the woman who escaped from Tibet sheds new light on China’s harsh policies aimed at bringing the region to heel.
item.dc:creator: Krishna Pokharel

item.title: Alberta Premier Says Vote on Separation From Canada Possible Next Year
item.description: Alberta Premier Danielle Smith said she and Prime Minister Mark Carney had a constructive phone call, but “until I see tangible proof of real change, Alberta will be taking steps to better protect ourselves from Ottawa.”
item.dc:creator: Paul Vieira

item.title: Israel Strikes Yemeni Port in Response to Houthi Hit on Airport
item.description: The Israeli attack targeted the port city of Hodeidah, which Israel alleges is used to transfer weapons from Iran.
item.dc:creator: Dov Lieber

item.title: Beijing’s ‘Made in China’ Plan Is Narrowing Tech Gap, Study Finds
item.description: The Xi Jinping strategy, which the U.S. criticized, unleashed enormous state support to boost competitiveness with the West.
item.dc:creator: Lingling Wei

item.title: Kim Jong Un’s Latest Gift to Russia Is Migrant Workers
item.description: The North Korean leader has helped Russian President Vladimir Putin withstand the pressure of the war in Ukraine by sending him soldiers and arms. His latest gift: workers.
item.dc:creator: Dasl Yoon

item.title: How Bad Is China’s Economy? The Data Needed to Answer Is Vanishing
item.description: Beijing has stopped publishing hundreds of statistics related to real estate, finance, unemployment and even soy sauce production, making it harder to know what’s going on in the country.
item.dc:creator: Jason Douglas

item.title: America’s New Pacific Army Commander Lays Out His China Strategy
item.description: Gen. Ronald Clark says “extraordinary times” in the region demand agile ground forces, new missile systems and a different way of thinking.
item.dc:creator: Timothy W. Martin

item.title: A Battlefield Death That Spelled the End for Russia’s Opposition
item.description: Ildar Dadin spent years arguing that nonviolent resistance was the best way to unseat Putin, until he took up arms against Russia.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Luxmoore

item.title: Trump, Mexico’s Sheinbaum Spar Over Drug Cartels
item.description: President Trump is pressuring Mexico to allow deeper U.S. military involvement in the fight against drug cartels.
item.dc:creator: Santiago Pérez

item.title: ‘Trump With a Pint’: How Nigel Farage Is Upending British Politics
item.description: The populist politician’s Reform UK party is soaring in the polls—and doing better at the ballot box—as voters lose patience with slow economic growth and high immigration.
item.dc:creator: Max Colchester

item.title: Who Killed the Sycamore Tree? Britain’s Latest True Crime Thriller
item.description: The beloved tree’s demise sent shock waves through the U.K. in 2023. The nation is still transfixed as two men accused of cutting it down stand trial.
item.dc:creator: Alistair MacDonald

item.title: The Potent Powder and ‘Narco-Subs’ Driving Cocaine’s Global Surge
item.description: Colombia grows more coca, drug labs process more powder and smuggling vessels traverse oceans, alarming U.S. antidrug officials.
item.dc:creator: Juan Forero

item.title: Moscow Digs In Over U.S. Peace Terms as Putin Declares Short Cease-Fire in May
item.description: It is the second time in less than two weeks that the Russian president has called a halt to fighting without committing to a long-term end to the war.
item.dc:creator: Georgi Kantchev

item.title: The Russian Military Moves That Have Europe on Edge
item.description: Putin is expanding bases and preparing to move more troops to European border regions far from Ukraine. “We’re expecting some conflict with NATO.”
item.dc:creator: Thomas Grove

item.title: Ukraine’s Crimea Lies at the Heart of Russia’s Invasion—and Trump’s Peace Plan
item.description: The military takeover of the peninsula was the first of Russia’s land grabs.
item.dc:creator: Jane Lytvynenko

item.title: Russian General Killed in Explosion as Witkoff Makes Push on Peace
item.description: Steve Witkoff arrived in Moscow for talks with Russian President Vladimir Putin as Moscow pressed ahead with its assault on Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Coles

item.title: JD Vance Sees an India That America Can Work With
item.description: The vice president says India and the U.S. are making progress in trade talks.
item.dc:creator: Shan Li

item.title: India Has a Golden Opportunity to Capture U.S. Business From China
item.description: The world’s most populous nation has long trailed not just China but also smaller countries with nimbler governments.
item.dc:creator: Tripti Lahiri

item.title: Betty Webb, Who Quit School to Keep Secrets for Britain During WWII, Dies at 101
item.description: She was part of a code-breaking operation, and spent the last decades of her life talking—and learning more—about her experiences
item.dc:creator: Chris Kornelis

item.title: U.K. Supreme Court Rules Trans Women Can’t Be Defined as Women
item.description: The decision could have far-reaching implications for the protections and freedoms given to transgender women in the U.K.
item.dc:creator: Gareth Vipers

item.title: Attacks on Darfur Relief Camps Threaten Bloody New Chapter in War
item.description: Fears are growing that a rebel militia is using violence to consolidate control in the famine-stricken region of Sudan.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Bariyo

item.title: In the Other Gaza, Trump’s War on Waste Baffles Mozambique
item.description: The White House claimed U.S. aid workers shipped 3.3 billion condoms to Hamas. They didn’t.
item.dc:creator: Michael M. Phillips

item.title: Al Qaeda Punctures Kenya’s Dreams for an Indian Ocean Trade Hub
item.description: Militants based next door in Somalia have stalled the $25 billion plan for an economic corridor across Kenya’s impoverished north.
item.dc:creator: Michael M. Phillips

item.title: While War Rages, Congo’s Neighbors Smuggle Out Its Gold and Mineral Wealth
item.description: The vast country is struggling to prevent Rwanda and Uganda from seizing some of its most valuable assets.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Bariyo

item.title: World’s Newest Country Teeters on Edge of Civil War
item.description: A standoff between the president and his deputy is threatening to tip South Sudan back into ethnic conflict.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Bariyo

item.title: Comedian Russell Brand Charged with Rape and Sexual Assault in U.K.
item.description: The allegations came from four women, London’s Metropolitan Police said.
item.dc:creator: Roshan Fernandez

item.title: Modi Positions India as Ally in Trump’s Illegal-Immigration Fight
item.description: India’s leader has supported the deportation of Indian citizens as New Delhi looks to safeguard U.S. relations and protect H-1B visas.
item.dc:creator: Tripti Lahiri

item.title: This Indian Festival Hosts More Pilgrims Than the Population of the U.S.
item.description: At least 400 million people are estimated to have attended the event, believed to be at least two millennia old and now drawing to a close.
item.dc:creator: Shan Li

item.title: Trump Calls India a Tariff King, a Title Modi Wants to Shed
item.description: With tariffs on imports averaging 14%, India is especially vulnerable to the reciprocal levies Trump says he will impose on some countries.
item.dc:creator: Tripti Lahiri

item.title: Families Battle Tech Giants as Australia Pushes for an Under-16 Social-Media Ban
item.description: The proposal marks the latest effort by political leaders worldwide to regulate children’s use of platforms, amid concerns that it is harming their mental health.
item.dc:creator: Mike Cherney

item.title: ‘We’ve Got to Kill’: Inside New Zealand’s Mission to Wipe Out Predators
item.description: Scientists debate whether a multibillion-dollar plan to eliminate invasive animals by 2050 is feasible.
item.dc:creator: Mike Cherney

item.title: France’s Macron Tries to Quell New Caledonia Riots With Globe-Crossing Trip
item.description: The French leader said he is open to suspending a voting-rights bill that sparked the riots once order is restored on the archipelago and talks resume between rival factions.
item.dc:creator: Stacy Meichtry

item.title: France Rushes Reinforcements to Riot-Stricken New Caledonia
item.description: Unrest in the overseas territory could derail President Emmanuel Macron’s efforts to restore French influence in the Indo-Pacific region.
item.dc:creator: Rhiannon Hoyle

item.title: Australia to Boost Defense Spending Amid U.S.-China Tensions
item.description: Australia is boosting its defense budget and rethinking its defense plans as strategic competition between the U.S. and China heats up in the Indo-Pacific region.
item.dc:creator: Mike Cherney
